Array Lists

An array list is part of the Java Collections Framework and provides a resizable array implementation. Array lists can grow and shrink in size dynamically and offer more flexibility. Some features of array lists are dynamic sizing and indexed access. Dynamic sizing automatically adjusts its size when elements are added or removed and indexed acess is where elements can be accessed through their index, similar to arrays. Before using an array list in Java, you would need to import it from the 'java.util' package: import java.utilArrayList; and then you are able to create an array list to hold specific types of objects: ArrayListnames = new ArrayList<>();.


Common Methods of Array Lists

add(E e): Adds the specified element to the ends of the list.

  • Example: 
                import java.util.ArrayList;

                public class Example {
                    public static void main(String[] args) {
                        ArrayList list = new ArrayList<>();
                        list.add("Apple");
                        list.add("Banana");
                        System.out.println(list); // Output: [Apple, Banana]
                    }
                }

add(int index, E Element): Inserts the specified element at the specified position in the list.

  • Example: 
                list.add(1, "Cherry");
            System.out.println(list); // Output: [Apple, Cherry, Banana]

remove(int index): Removes the element at the specified position in the list.

  • Example: 
                list.remove(1);
            System.out.println(list); // Output: [Apple, Banana]

remove(Object o): Removes the first occurrence of the specified element from the list.

  • Example: 
                list.remove("Banana");
            System.out.println(list); // Output: [Apple]

get(int index): Returns the element at the specified position in the list.

  • Example: 
                String element = list.get(0);
            System.out.println(element); // Output: Apple

set(int index, E element): Replaces the element at the specified position in the list with the specified element.

  • Example: 
                list.set(0, "Apricot");
            System.out.println(list); // Output: [Apricot]

size(): Returns the number of elements in the list.

  • Example: 
                int size = list.size();
            System.out.println(size); // Output: 1

contains(Object o): Returns 'true' if the list contains the specified element.

  • Example: 
                boolean containsApple = list.contains("Apple");
            System.out.println(containsApple); // Output: false

clear(): Removes all of he elements from the list.

  • Example: 
                list.clear();
            System.out.println(list);

isEmpty(): Returns 'true' if the list contains no elements.

  • Example: 
                boolean isEmpty = list.isEmpty();
            System.out.println(isEmpty); // Output: true
